column4: hi guys, is there any easy-to-use linux app that allows me to completely clone my laptops hard drive, so that - if it goes wrong, I am able to put it all back, *exactly* how it was before? .. I have a couple of USB hard drive and I'm hoping to be able to do this (I'm going to upgrade to feisty)
dd
it's already installed, it's a standard tool, $ man dd
ringo hmm, I think you're over judging my intelligence... I don't like command line stuff. The more I can avoid it the better.
you're not going to find anything simpler than dd
if you can't work out dd then I doubt you can work out an equivalent gui, if such a thing exists
uhm, so you're saying linux has no GUI based partition backup tool?
there likely is, but i've never looked for one
$ sudo dd if=/dev/sda1 of=backup
ok ok... so, if I do successfully backup my linux whole HD to my USB HD, how do i put it back if it goes wrong? (as in, command etc)
$ sudo if=backup of=/dev/sda
does DD have documentation?
man dd
you can combine it with gzip to compress the images too
do you want to backup the whole drive or just one partition?
I don't really mind... I have a blank hard drive.
what exactly do you want to backup?
my whole laptops hd
ok, so the entire hdd
it won't take forever, it'll just be however long it takes to read the entire disk
mount the new drive, cd into it, $ sudo if=/dev/hda of=hdabackup bs=1M
ringo ok, well before all of this, I need to format my usb hard drive
be back later? it takes a few minutes to format a drive
yeah, back later as in, 5 minutes or so
